Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 05:42AM ecpelkey wrote: There is a magic mouthwash out there that has to be prescribed b/c it is a compound of MAylox, Ladocaine and Benedryl.  My insurance did not cover the compound and it is a bit expensive (not sure why) so, I opted for my MO's homemade recipe of 1/2 cap of Listerine, 1/2 cap peroxide, 1 tsp salt and 1 tsp baking soda.  It helps get rid of the sandpaper feeling and mouth sores.  Tast buds are still pretty much shot though.  I only did the olive oil on infusion day before and after.  I think around Day 4 after is when i got the sandpaper mouth.  I am day 10 now and feel fine...just the taste of food is off.  I do use olive oil on the corners of my mouth to help with the cracking.
Posts.Title: January 2012 chemo ely Momof2inME

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2012 04:38PM ecpelkey wrote: I guess this is the group I should be in since I will be starting Chemo this month.  I am deciding which treatment plan to take.  I was actually given 2 different plans by 2 different Oncs.  Either A/C *4 +T or T/C *4.  Tonight I will be weighing pros and cons on the SEs of each and reading a lot...I am ready to get this ball rolling.
Posts.Title: January 2012 chemo ely Momof2inME

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2012 07:18PM ecpelkey wrote: hi all.  I have been reading everyone's posts and they have been veru helpful and encouraging.  I am on T/C x4 (possibly 6) with radiation after.  I had my first infusion last Tuesday, so I am on Day 8.  I haven't had to deal with too many SEs.  Had bloodwork done yesterday and it was low but my MO thinks I will bounce back OK.  I did not do Nuelesta this time.  MO and I chose not to do it to see how I do without. My concern is I have small kids and one that just started preschool for the first time. I am scared of the germs they bring home.  DEB267: What type of rash did you have?  I have had an acne break out and a few itchy bumps on my chest.  I told MO about it yesterday, but he didn't mention any changes.  Jennt28:  I am the crazy one that posted on your FB about pics.  I realized I have been reading posts but haven't actually posted myself.  Guess I am a stalker of sorts:) I am on another forum as well and I have commented there...could be confusion...been known to happen. Not sure how I will handle chemo brain...I still have leftover mommy brain.  Ladies: all of you have given me  hope and encouragement to move forward.
Posts.Title: January 2012 chemo ely Momof2inME

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2012 08:32AM ecpelkey wrote: I have to say today is the worst I have felt.  Temp is 99.9 and I keep having ovualtion twinges.  I left a message for my MO.  I figured I overdid yesterday b/c I raked a portion (small portion) of my yard. I have been drinking a Boost every morning.  Have any of you had those.  They aren't  bad (well, the chocolate ones anyway).  My aunt had to take chemo dugs for another illness and they helped her.  Just thought I would pass it on.  Also olive oil in the cracks of my mouth have helped with the cracking.  As soon as I felt it starting, I started putting a little bit on.  Hair is there but OILY...I have never had such oily hair before...Just chalking it up as another SE.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2012 06:09AM ecpelkey wrote: So, I submitted a question to MD Anderson regarding the 4 versus 6 TC and this is the response I got: In looking at the treatment guidelines that MD Anderson uses for treating invasive breast cancer, almost all of the chemotherapy regimens which I saw indicated 4 cycles of treatment. I did not see any regimens which we use in which 6 cycles of treatment were indicated. You can view our standard treatment guidelines for invasive breast cancer at the following link: http://www.mdanderson.org/education-and-research/resources-for-professionals/clinical-tools-and-resources/practice-algorithms/ca-treatment-breast-invasive-web-algorithm.pdf The various treatment pathways for invasive breast cancer will be found on the first 4 pages of the guidelines. Detailed information regarding the chemotherapy principles we use are found on pages 7 and 8 of the guidelines. Of course, each patient's case is different, and while there are no standard pathways listed which call for 6 cycles, it is possible that this may be appropriate in certain cases where a patient's physicians feel that extra treatment cycles will offer a more optimum treatment outcome. Our breast cancer specialists would typically offer a treatment plan that is based on the specific needs and circumstances in a patient's case; this may reflect a standard treatment pathway, a variation of one of those pathways, or something totally different, including a clinical trial. You may wish to address with your physician the reasons why he/she is considering extra cycles of chemotherapy in your specific case. I hope that this is helpful. Please contact me again if I may be of any further assistance. Sincerely, Kyle S. Evans Health Information Specialist, askMDAnderson Public Education Office 877-MDA-6789 I have my appt on Tuesday for bloodwork and I am going to discuss it with my MO again, but I am pretty sure 4 is IT for me.  I have been mored tired this round and this IBS thing is bugging the crap out of me (haha...I wish it were) .  I have just been annoyed with the office lately anyway.  I was scheduled jury duty on the 19th (the day before round 4) and the nurse told me she would have a letter to get out of jury duty ready for me last week....it wasn't ready.  That along with the MO not calling me back had me in a tizzy.  Anyway, I was assured the letter would be there at my next appt.  I am OK today other than cramping and diarrhea...ugh.  I did take my boys to our downtown First Friday Event.  I have friends that just opened a new restaurant.  We really didn't make it in the restaurant, but we did take a stroll and visit and it was nice to get out of the house.  I met another lady that is going through treatment for BC in the bookstore.  Breaks my heart that so many are going through this.  Hope everyone is feeling OK.  Looks like I have 1 more round to do.....YAY!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 11:44PM ecpelkey wrote: It has been a while since I posted anything.  I was concerned about which treatment plan and oncologist to choose.  I had a PetScan, which was clear, and have decided to use the first Doc I saw, but go with T/Cx 4 (possibly 6 if I tolerate it well).  My first chemo is tomorrow morning. No chemo classes offered here. They just walk you through everything while it is happening.  I took the steroid pills today and I have a prescription for finergan (I think that is the name) for nausea.  Anyone know about this med?  I have heard it before but I thought it was an over the counter med for nausea. should I request something stronger?  I don not do nausea and vomiting well at all.  I am googling tonight.  The steroid helped me get everything done that I have procrastinated doing TODAY.  WOW...good stuff (at least the first day).  I have been keeping up with your posts and most of you are half way done, but I have gotten great ideas from you all to help with the SEs.  Thanks for the posts.  Good luck to all of you!  I am praying that all goes well tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 07:30PM ecpelkey wrote: I had my first T/C on Tuesday and all went well.  There was no "chemo school".  I sat with the nurse for the first half hour with her going over the meds and SEs. The chemo area was semi- private partitioned off by a curtain with a recliner chair, TV, and WIFI is available. Nurse told me they got a nice donation and new chairs with heat and massage, etc have been purchased, but of course it will be after my time....bummer. The nice thing they do is bring breakfast or lunch to you if you are there during those time frames. It was nice to have breakfast and a newspaper brought to me before everything got started.  Kinda put me at ease. It was quiet that day (not too many people there).  I was scared the port was going to be painful, but it really wasn't.  I had ativan in my meds and the nurse said I may sleep, but I was awake and a bit loopy throughout the procedure.  So far, I have done well...my biggest complaint is indigestion. No nausea.  I did wake up with nightsweats at 3am the first night, but all was fine. I am trying to go without the Nuelesta shot.  I am hoping all goes well.  I was scared my Tx would be put off b/c my 3 year old had Strep last Friday.  He has been on antibiotics and no one else has gotten sick.  I Lysoled and Bleached the heck out of my house all weekend too. Since my diagnosis, we decided to put my 3 year old in a preschool...not sure about the timing, b/c kids have to pick up EVERY germ as soon as they start school.  It is only his 2nd week (fingers crossed he stays well).  Unfortunately, the first day of him starting school (last week) his teacher was out having a breast biopsy, which did turn out to be cancer.  She and I have been chatting about procedures, etc during pick up and drop off times. I really hated hearing someone else having to go through this mess...it makes me sad.  Sorry to write a book here.  I do very much enjoy reading all of the posts and it has been helpful.  I did the olive oil swish before and after treatment and iced my nails during treatment.  I am getting a pixie hair cut this weekend. I have already donated 10 inches of hair to Locks of Love and currently have an inverted bob...going shorter every other week...My MIL does hair:)  I am even enjoying the bitchy comments...I have already apologized to my husband for anything that I could possibly say or do during all of this. thank you for the posts, b/c it is helpful to know there are others going through the same thing.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 12:04AM ecpelkey wrote: WOW...just when I though I was having minimal SEs, yesterday I felt like a truck had run over me.  I kept having chills, bodyaches, and low grade fever (100.1 was the highest).  I am a normal 96-97 degrees, so when I get a low grade fever, I feel it. I am Day 11 from Tx today.  I feel better this morning and so far 97.1.  I know my white counts are low at 2.1.  They were low on Tuesday when I saw my MO.  Called him yesterday and he said this was normal and to call if my fever went over 101.  I have quarantined myself in my room , b/c of course, my 3 year old woke up in the middle of the night coughing.  AGH!!  The timing!  Luckily hubby is off this weekend and he can take the kids away for a bit today. So if I have the Nuelesta shot, should I feel these symptoms from the shot, but feel better when the counts are supposed to be dropped (Days 7-14)? I am weighing the odds of getting the shot next infusion. If my counts are still low on Tuesday when i see my MO, he said he could give me Nuepogen (sp) to boost the counts.  Has anyone done this?
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 04:37AM ecpelkey wrote: So sorry I haven't been back on...WOW...miss a few days and there is SOOOO much to read and catch up on.  Congrats to those ladies completing their last rounds.  YOU DID IT!!  This week has been interesting...I had chills, body aches, and fevers last weekend.  My MO phoned in Levaquin to keep me  out of the ER, which helped.  I was feeling much better by Monday.  But it turns out the source of infection was actually my incision from my sentinel biopsy, which was done in November.  Monday it was red and swollen.  Saw the MO on Tuesday and my blood count was back up, but he changed the antibiotics to care for my arm.  Saw the surgeon and he tried to drain fluid, but nothing came out.  Went back to Surgeon on Friday and he did an ultrasound to see what was going on.  I have pockets of fluid under the swelling.  He was able to drain a little but now I am looking at another surgery to get the fluid out....I am so pissed!  This will delay my 2nd infusion of chemo which is supposed to be Tuesday.  I will know more on Monday.  I have appointments with both my MO and my surgeon to discuss the next steps.  Also, my whole family battled illness this week.  My youngest had to do breathing treatments, my 6 year old had sore throat and ear aches, and my husband had a sinus infection.  EVERYONE was home sick on Thursday and Friday.  I have spent most of the day Lysoling and bleaching (again).  What a way to spend the "good" chemo days, huh.  I also went to the Look Good Feel Better program Tuesday night. I figured they would have mentioned something about parabens in makeup and things to steer clear from, but instead they talked about the potential to contaminate your makeup and the importance of not "double dipping" your applicators in your make up.  I use Bare Escentualls make up and have been trying to figure out an easy and inexpensive cleaning for my brushes.  The stuff they sale is expensive and I am not sure a daily cleaning will help the brushes last.  Any ideas??? My artist friend came up with a Chick Superhero character named NED.  She is supposed to be emailing me the pic.  As soon as I get it, I will forward onto here or a link or something.  Thanks ladies for allowing the "vent".  Here's hoping everyone has a GOOD week this week!!  I am chilling out and enjoying my kids.  I may even take them to Jekyll to hunt for treasures:)
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 02:08PM ecpelkey wrote: Well, Round 2 is a GO tomorrow.  I woke up in the night last night with drainage from the swelling in my arm (sorry, gross).  My MO took a look this AM and the swelling has gone down considerably and since I am not running a fever and my blood count is up, I am good to go tomorrow.  YAY. I am excited since I had everything mapped out for this round as far as "who is available to pick up my child today because I feel like crap" AND my mom is visiting for 2 weeks while my husband is working nights, so I will have someone here during the "yuck" times for me and my kids. I was really happy to not have to change that. My surgeon mentioned needing divine intervention over the weekend in order to get the chemo tomorrow....well, how is that for intervening? ...Thank you God!  annie: I have not shaved anything in quite a while. Kinda gave up on it figuring I may be hairless soon anyway.  I think I need to get the disposable mascara applicators b/c I really only wear lipstick and mascara most of the time.  I guess I will have to try the liner if and when the lashes fall out.  Have any of you heard of TigerLily Foundation? It is for women going through breast cancer ages 15-40.  They sent me a nice bag with an all natural soap and lotion in it made by Nubian Heratage.  Smells wonderful and all natural ingredients.  Also, my friend sent me a link to Cleaning for a Reason.  You should see if it is offered in your areas.  It is companies that volunteer time cleaning for cancer patients.  I am wierd about other people cleaning my house but I did check out the site and it is worth checking out if you need the help.  Wavewhisperer: you bringing up the nail salon made me think of why I NEVER go to nail salons anymore.  I got a fungus at one years ago in one of my toes and it still isn't the same....(I am secretly hoping I lose that nail during chemo).  Ladies: I wish I could remember everyone individually but I am on a steroid high and am thinking of 1000+ things even as I type right now....mind is a racing.  I wish you all well and hope SEs stay at a low for all of you and thank God everyday for finding this group to chat with.  Thank you and Good Night!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2012 10:08PM ecpelkey wrote: Hey ladies!  I am so sorry I have not been posting on here.  It has been a busy few weeks and since finishing chemo, I have enjoyed being somewhat normal...ha.  Anyway, I called this morning to find out if my RO knows when I will be beginning Rads ( I thought I would hear something already)...anyway, looks like I will go Monday for my next appt.  My colonoscopy is scheduled for Wed and I am finishing with PT (slight lymphdema) next week too. I still need to find out about the port...whether I need to go have it removed or not.  I hate hanging in limbo. I am good with getting it removed, but since the MO, RO, BS and the rest of the cancer board meet and discuss my case, I figured I would wait and see if that was discussed and what the RO says about it.  I have a question...my MO gave me the prescription for tamoxifen and said I could start taking it when I was ready.  Meaning, I could take it while going through Rads or I could wait until I finished (again, he left it up to me).  Are you ladies taking it while doing rads?  I am nervous about Radiation....more than I wa about chemo. Is that wierd?  And I want to make sure if there are any SE to anything...I know what I am doing and not doing several things at once...does that make sense?  Plus, I wanted to get through this colonoscopy, too.  And make sure everything is good with that.  Glad to hear everyone is doing well.  Stay well y'all!!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 08:42PM ecpelkey wrote: Hi Neli I was reading some of the posts and I felt I should tell you that I was on the fence about doing it too.  Even my gynocologist called me and stressed the importance.  My friend were sending me death threats (joke).  After MUCH deliberation and information overload, I decided to bite the bullet and do this.  I have a 3 year old and a 6 year old and I really would like to see them grow up.  My first infusion was Jan 17 and I go for round 2 Feb 7.  I opted to not have the neulesta shot this time to see how I would do with out it...let's just say I am going to get the shot the next infusions.  As far as SEs...they are managable.  Read these posts from past and present and you will see that there are remedies to help you get through it, such as icing your finger nails during the treatment or olive oil swishes to help with the mouth issues.  You can do it.  I agree that you need to be comfortable with your MO...that was one of my issues in the beginning, but I found one that I am comfortable with.  Get more opinions if you need to feel better about your decision.  Goodluck!  These women are all here for the same thing and will support you.
Posts.Title: TC (Taxotere/Cytoxan) chemo Neli Lumpynme

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 04:53AM ecpelkey wrote: Hi!  New here and have been reading posts to decide which therapy I should take.  I am having a hard time since one oncologist wanted to do A/C treatment and Toxol.  My 2nd oncologist opinion was to do what is called the 3rd Generation Regimen of Taxotiere and Cytoxan with radiation after that.  I have not made a decision, but am leaning more toward the T/C treament. My (possible future) oncologist wants to induce Menopause with a drug called Zolodex first before starting the treatments.  Has anyone else done this?  I had a lumpectomy in November and got the patholgy report back Dec 8.  I live in a smaller community, so I am not sure who i would see for a 3rd opinion without traveling to a larger city.  I thought I would put it out there to see if anyone is going through what I am about to experience.  Any info helps. Thanks

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 01:59PM ecpelkey wrote: HeatherWeather:  I love the NED tattoo idea.  I actually have a friend that is an artist and I texted her the idea of NED to see what she comes up with.  She made me a Cancer Monster the other day which I love.  I'll see if there is a way I can post a pic of it.  For Christmas, my brother (he is 23) got a pink ribbon tattoo in my honor...I thought it was very sweet of him to do.  I am considering a tattoo after all is done.  Even though I love my brother's tat, I was thinking of something different than the usual pink ribbon...I really liked your idea. I am not into the PINK stuff, although it is beginning to grow on me.  I hope you don't mind that I asked my friend.  She is very creative and she is an illustrator and artist and pretty good. I'll keep you posted if she comes up with something.

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 12:47AM ecpelkey wrote: Hi ladies. I'm sorry I have not been on in a while.  I took a break from the forum and missed a lot.  Round 3 is scheduled for Tuesday for me.  Round 2 was almost a breeze for me...which concerns me.  I have had dreams that I didn't get the meds I was supposed to get, that a bag was left out. In reality, the SEs have been very minimal, which has me wonder if there something to my dreams.  Crazy, right?? I did have major indigestion and I have been tired, but really that was it throughout the past 2 weeks. I have also been in a bit of denial about having to do chemo b/c I felt so good  but  the anxiety struck yesterday when I started having issues.  I am having issues with my bowels (TMI, I know), but I need to know if anyone else has had this problem.  I have had mucus and blood with my stool.  I am also having my period, which is off schedule by a week and a half, if it is indeed my period. I really thought the chemo would have induced menopause.  I called my MO yesterday, but I haven't gotten a response and today I was busy with the big local consignment sale that I didn't call again, but probably should have.  I have no fever.  I had cramping yesterday, but not so much today.  Today, indigestion feeling again.  My plan is to call again in the morning.  I have an appt for bloodwork on Monday already.  Idon'tdosick: I am like you and have been trying to figure out causes. I am wanting new pots and pans b/c the ones I have are teflon and I am getting rid of plastics regardless of what # it is. I have my whole pantry of tupperware that I am converting to glass jars, when I can afford to switch.  I have been switching to natural soaps and I don't use deoderant/antiperspirant anymore.  I am currently planning a garden to grow a few things organic.  I have been wanting a chicken coop for a while, even before my diagnosis.  I have 2 friends that have one and love their chickens.  My husband says that I am being neurotic about all of the changes, but it is happening.  Chickens and all...just wait:)    I had to laugh about the hair incident. Last night we went to my son's basketball game and there was a storm coming in and my husband was laughing because I was holding my hair on in the wind.  I wanted to tell you ladies about Crickett's Answer for a Reason ( I think that is it) anyway, they have funding for wigs and other things for breast cancer patients.  I am getting a wig from them in a few days.  My insurance doesn't cover cranial prostetics.     I have indeed missed you all.  I got in a bit of a funk and just didn't want to talk about, read about or anything breast cancer, especially since I felt fine.  Reality is back now and I realized how much I needed you all, b/c no one around me knows how to answer my questions or understands what I am feeling right now. I am glad to hear many of you are done or will be done soon. I am still waiting to find out if I end at #4 or if I will have 6 rounds. I am ready for the countdown. Goodnight.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 12:56AM ecpelkey wrote: It is Crickett's Answer for Cancer. I have hearing issues, by day sensitive to noise and at night I get the swishy sounds of my heart beating.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 10:05PM ecpelkey wrote: I am sorry I am not good at posting, but I have been reading and keeping up.  Joyce~ it is so sad when our babies have to deal with this Cancer Crap at such young ages.  I am so sorry.  I went to have bloodwork today and had a new PA instead of my MO.  She was great and a BC survivor 4 years out.  She actually asked me today how I was feeling mentally.  She said that around the end of treatments we start feeling a bit down. That we have to find a new normal for ourselves and move forward and to really lean on our support system and let them know how we feel.  I just thought I would share with you. I am moody but I am not having crying spells yet. Seems to be part of the cycle of this crap we have to go through.  She ordered a chest xray for the wierd tenderness that I am having in my ribcage (new ailment) and I have an appt set up tomorrow for the IBS with a GI Doc...YAY.  My LAST Chemo is still scheduled for Tuesday.  I am so ready to move past this part.   Rachel~ I am so glad that I didn't have to do the 5th and 6th round...Hang in there and rest when you can.  It will all be done soon:) Thanks all for posting about the rads.  How long of a break was there between chemo and rads? We are trying to squeeze in a vacation if we can before I start rads.  I am hoping to feel up for a vacation.  Y'all take care.  Deb~  Love the idea of St Augustine:)  Contact me if you ever want to meet up for coffee or anything.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 04:41AM ecpelkey wrote: An add:  My husband buzzed my hair on Wednesday.  It isn't as bad as I thought it would be.  On Tuesday, my hair was literally blowing off of my head in the wind.  I felt it was time to shave it.  So, now I am a member of the NO HAIR tribe.  Time to find a good wig now.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2012 02:58PM ecpelkey wrote: So, I called out my MO today for NOT calling me back on Friday and so did his nurse.  She said "I even gave you a reminder call."  HA.  He was very apologetic, but at the same time I was very annoyed and I think he sensed it.  I also got annoyed with him b/c he goes off on tangents unrelated to my care.  I told him that with my 'chemo brain' that I really need to only hear about my care so I could focus on retaining that info and not be confused with his stories....it shut him up.  ( I have been very blunt with people lately)  As far as the mucus and blood.  It is common to have issues from the chemo, but I probably have IBS and he would like for me to see a GI Doc, but try to wait until I complete chemo unless it worsens or doesn't get better. The blood is related to hemorroids (yep, feel them now).  As far as the menstruation, my system is out of whack from the chemo.  It could be onset of chemo induced menopause or I could bleed for a while.  UGH. (Can't I at least save some $ on $6 cardboard and cotton since I am spending it elsewhere?)  My counts were great and I am ready to go tomorrow for round #3.  I will get Neulesta on Wed.  As far as why I would be doing 6 Tx over 4 Tx of TC...originally, my MO suggested that it would be an option if I did well with the meds.  NOW, he thinks that 4 is enough, but he is leaving the decision to me.  I can do more treatments if I want to (WHAT!! Yeah sure sounds fun!!)  I asked him about scans and such to make sure the chemo is working and his answer was that I would get scans 6 months to a year later to make sure all was well (again, WHAT!!)  I need answers NOW!!  He said I have markers and each blood work order that I have had shows the level of proteins in my lymphatic system. It fluctuates during chemo, but as long as it is under 38, it is good.  My last one was 16.  (I didn't write it down and my brain has forgotten the rest of what he said about this....Does everyone else need to write EVERYTHING down??)  My brain is shot.  Anyway, has anyone heard this?  Josie4: I had to give up dairy while nursing my youngest since he had a milk protein allergy.  I was the thinnest I had been in a long time.  Of course, when I stopped nursing the ice cream was back and so was the weight.  I have considered giving it up again. I am trying to go organic but it is so dang expensive to eat healthy.  I am such a meat and potatoes girl and being southern...comfort foods are a staple for me, not sure about the raw diet.  Someone (a friend that was a little anti chemo) gave me the Hallaluyah Diet book about going vegan and and juicing.  The man that wrote the book is a minister that claims to have cured his cancer eating raw veggies and juicing.  Check out the website.  It is interesting.  I just don't know if I could do it, I LOVE FOOD.  CKK: Gonna get with you on FB.  Look for me.  I am NOT a gardener.  I grew tomatoes (for the 1st time) and bell peppers and jalepenos and herbs last year in containers.  I am wanting my husband to build me an above ground area to plant a few other things this year. I really have no clue what I am doing, but I have such an interest in it.  Do you do pinterest?  I started a board for gardening ideas there that has been helping me with planning.  I want to at least have items for salsa (which I love) and salads and a few additional veggies. BaileyBump:  The reason my husband says I am neurotic is b/c I am wanting it ALL to go. some of the plastics are 'good' plastics.  There is a list somewhere that found that discussed the differences in the plastic #s.  It might have been here.  I can't remember, I wil check.  No cooking in plastics, though!  I used to keep water bottles in my car and drink them later, but not anymore. If your teflon pans are scratched (which mine were) and there is heat, that is when the (cancer causing) fumes get out and contaminate food. RachelVK: I have had such an easy time with #2. I am scared #3 will be ROUGH.  My husband has to work straight through March 10-20 12-16 hour shifts at his company and probably longer and right now he is uncertain which shift. It could be night or day shift, so he won't be around to help and my mom doesn't think she can come back in March after all. I am scared I won't have help this month, although my friends have all offered to help out. I don't ask for help well.  And being normal helps me cope. My poor mom was here after #2 and I wouldn't let her do anything because I felt fine.  GracieG: Question, Did you ice your nails during infusion?  I have to say,  I went to see my cousin today while at the hospital (his wife gave birth to twins this AM)  and he said "I really like your haircut".  I told him it was a wig and he said he couldn't tell.  WOW.  THANKS DEB267!!  And his wife owns a hair salon.  Cool, huh??  Made me feel good b/c he is a pretty straight telling it guy and he is family and if it looked like crap he would have told me:)  OKOK...My steroids are causing me to write a book. Sorry.  Y'all have a great night!!  Round #3 at 8:15AM  Thanks!!  ~E
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane
